Rules
Day 1 Begins || Day 1 Ends
Day 2 Begins || Day 2 Ends
Day 3 Begins || Day 3 Ends
Day 4 Begins || Day 4 Ends
Day 5 Begins || Day 5 Ends
Day 6 Begins || Day 6 Ends
Endgame

RulesVoting, lynching, and deadline
To vote, bold the words “vote: playername” or use vote tags.
Though not strictly necessary, it is appreciated if you unvote before voting someone else.
It takes the votes of half of the living players, either plus 1 or rounded up, to lynch.
It takes half, rounded up, but not plus 1 to no-lynch.
Once the final vote has been cast, no further unvotes or votes will be counted.
If you have been lynched, you may make one “bah” post the next day, as long as it does not say anything game related. In addition, if you've been lynched, you may continue to talk until I post the lynch scene.
Day deadline will be 2 weeks, with possible exceptions for replacements.
If there is no majority at deadline, there will be no lynch.
Night deadlines will be 72 hours, unless someone is replaced, in which case I will make a 3 day extension.
If you go without posting for 72 hours without providing advance notice of it(I don't check the V/LA thread), I will prod you. You then have 48 hours to respond. If you don't, I will replace you.

Etiquette
This is a game. Be respectful and have fun. Yes, you should play to win, but in my opinion, having fun is more important.
Do not post in small sizes, post in colors that blend in with the forum background, or in any way try to hinder the legibility of your posts.
Do not communicate about this game outside of this thread, unless otherwise stated in your role PM.
Quoting anything other than votecounts or rules from me is not allowed.
Teal is my color. Using it will be considered impersonating the mod. Don't do it.
If you somehow can, don't edit or delete posts.
If you need to contact me, either PM me, or if it's something like incorrect votecounts, tell me in-thread.

If you break the rules…
Punishment will be decided on severity of offense. For severe infractions, you may get mod-killed, which will end the day if you're town, but not if you're anything else. You may get force-replaced. If the infraction is less severe, you may get a strike. You only get 3 strikes, and then I will force replace you.

Finally, rules are subject to change. I may change things at my discretion, and I will inform you if I do. If I make a mistake, please say so politely.


This game will have 1 Mafia group and 1 Werewolf group.
Sample Role PM wrote:Welcome to Mini ####, XXXX. You are a Town Citizen.
You have no active abilities but your vote, which you are advised to use wisely.

You win when all threats to the town are dead.
Game is here.

Role PM's will be out sometime within the next 15 minutes.
All roles are out! Game will begin once 12 people confirm. Confirm via response PM.

Day 1 begins. Deadline is April 21st.

I assumed the point of the RVS was to randomly vote until that point when someone started to act scummy.

I thought it would be assumptious and over stepping my bounds to vote for one of these fine Americans, Australians and wherever the hell these other players who haven't posted hail from at this point in the game. I don't have some sort of joke vote and I have no idea what an empking is so I'm not gonna vote for something just because it is, I am not a empking bigot like Jeromus. I also find that the RVS tends to allow someone of the anti-town persuasion lead and easy and blameless bandwagon on a harmless townie who was just trying to do his civic duty. I just don't like to vote without an actual tangible, quotable reason to put my vote down. I am also partially against starting a game without a full roster of confirms, so I vote nobody, absolutely nobody, not until I've got a couple of pages to read and won't be bullied into any such votes.

Plus, I rather like putting myself out there as I am quite the attention whore.

Yes indeed. I like also enjoy breaking RVS as quickly as possible, as the scum routinely act the fool in RVS in order to establish themselves as active when it least counts. So the first one that breaks the norm in RVS is typically scum.

You see that is a bit of a WIFOM, isn't it? In the same way I could just vote conventionally and it could be argued that I'm just trying to blend in. At this point we only have 9 of 13 players posted (most of those only once) and 1 unconfirmed, I see no reason to to randomly vote for someone. I could've posted after kanye and gone "yo, yo, I'mma let you finish but hezlucky, hezlucky is the best bandwagon of all time" and voted him that would've accomplished just as much as my non-vote.

The way I see it, it's quite easy to point at an unconventional post and say that its scummy. I do agree that it is quite an easy wagon for the anti-town forces to latch onto and it being day 1, its also fairly easy to brush it off and fade back into the woodwork.

Yes indeed. I like also enjoy breaking RVS as quickly as possible, as the scum routinely act the fool in RVS in order to establish themselves as active when it least counts. So the first one that breaks the norm in RVS is typically scum.


So if I read you correctly, breaking RVS is good for town but the one who does this is typically scum?

Why did you take so long to confirm?

Occult, what did you mean by symbolic?

Really, Occult (and others), how often does the RVS lead to legitimate votes and bandwagons that end in the Day 1 lynch? I've read a few games around this site so far (and from my experience in mafia in general) and from what I can tell, very rarely does the first few sets of votes actually go through. To see them as legitimate threats seems a little silly and paranoid; I find it had to believe that anyone should be so threatened by the first stages of the game that they will not vote.

"I just don't like to vote without an actual tangible, quotable reason to put my vote down."

Yeah, but isn't the vote the most powerful tool the town has in both voting off mafia and discerning information about the players?

I don't like the fact that we started already, feels... premature. I'd prefer to have waited a couple more days, had a full roster of players ready to go and then started. Others may disagree, but it is where I stand on it.

Now, yes while its true that the RVS doesn't just automatically lead to a lynch, its just plain useless. I'm not "threatened by them" I really don't like the fact that it is expected to random vote. Yes, it is our most powerful tool, but doing it randomly does not help, does it? You randomly voted for McGriddle, what did you learn from that vote? Nothing. My non-vote has started an actual conversation, I now have responses from IS, darkdude and yourself. I would say I have actually contributed to the game where as you just jumped up, pointed at me and voted for me for saying a prefer to carefully look at the evidence rather then put up some sorta random absurdness? That's just absurd, I'm not going throw my vote around for no reason, especially if not everyone has posted. Would you find it anti-town if someone jumped onto a bandwagon without reasoning?

I like that you at least have a question for me to respond to. I prefer contributions to the game, that have reasoning, not random voting. You must realize that while voting is the town's most powerful tool, is it also a great tool for the mafia to use. Especially with the uninformed and new. Its like a gun is great for protection, but don't shoot everyone who happens to step on your lawn.

In my mind at this point, we have something tangible to talk about, we have an event that we can discuss, we have reactions to look at and we are not even out of the first page, this is what I prefer over multiple pages of randomness. That just lets the anti-town bide their time and stay in the shadows.

Okay. Read up time.

Standard PSA:
For the uninitiated, I rank my suspects from 0 (absolutely town) - 100 (absolutely scum). Everybody starts at 50. Because I don't believe in towntells and am skeptical about most scumtells, it is common for people to stay at 50. 50 does not mean "no opinion" - it means "I don't see scumtells" from this person. Absent claims etc. I will always vote the person with the highest score.

23: Elsa+5. His reasoning here for voting Occult (who, by this stage, appears to be the candidate du jour) is at best unclear and at worst inconsistent. In the first paragraph he, rightly, argues that RVS rarely leads to legitimate votes and bandwagons. He then, however, attacks Occult for not voting on the basis that the vote is town's most powerful tool (wrong, it's reasoning; votes are, or should be, just an expression of reasoning). I've had some difficulty working out why this post seems inconsistent, and I think it can be best expressed as follows: a player who thinks that RVS is largely useless (as Elsa appears to) should not get upset by another player refusing to vote in RVS. After all if you think votes are so useful that a player should cast a vote without reasoning (which is what Occult refused to do), then you presumptively also think that RVS is useful.
27: Hez+5 contingent on no future explanation of this vote. I can't see any evidence for Elsa being "apologetic".
33: McG+5 Despite the use of hyperbole ("obv wagoning is obv"), I can't actually see how this wagoning at all. Nobody had changed votes since Hez's post and, more to the point, you don't even consider whether the vote was justified or not.

It's definitely the hardest part about using a points system.

Basically, the way I do it is I pick the base value for an "average strength" scumtell (ie. 5) and then give out scores based on how I would rank a particular scumtell relative to that. There will obviously be small discrepancies between, say, whether you give a 7 or an 8 for a moderately serious scumtell, but provided the overall range is large enough, small differences shouldn't matter too much.

vollkan wrote:I've tried using probability once in the past, but I found it took a lot of time to do, and, since the main thing is just tracking relative suspicions, I don't think it would add anything significant.


It is only that a system based on the addition/subtraction of points does not reflect the way probabilities of hypotheses change as evidence accumulates. I feel that with your system you would be more tempted to give out points based on how much it will reflect in the total score. Because the rate of accumulation is inaccurate, you may feel inclined to "fix" this using your own intuition. For a Bayesian system you need only be sure of how strong the tell is (more precisely the likelihood of the evidence generated due to suspect being scum, compared to town), and the math will do all else for you. There will only be room for error in your judgement, as opposed to your system itself.

The other thing is that I see in a long game you might approach 0 or 100 without actual confirmations. I'm assuming in that case you'll move the ends of the spectrum even further. With a probability system you won't have that. But that's not a big issue.

The most important thing I can see is: you can rate the accuracy of your judgement once you collect enough data (play enough games). Your predicted probability at the lynch should be exactly the rate at which the lynched player flips scum. You will know how to adjust based on how much and in which direction your prediction deviates.

I feel that with your system you would be more tempted to give out points based on how much it will reflect in the total score. Because the rate of accumulation is inaccurate, you may feel inclined to "fix" this using your own intuition. For a Bayesian system you need only be sure of how strong the tell is (more precisely the likelihood of the evidence generated due to suspect being scum, compared to town), and the math will do all else for you. There will only be room for error in your judgement, as opposed to your system itself.

The other thing is that I see in a long game you might approach 0 or 100 without actual confirmations. I'm assuming in that case you'll move the ends of the spectrum even further. With a probability system you won't have that. But that's not a big issue.

The most important thing I can see is: you can rate the accuracy of your judgement once you collect enough data (play enough games). Your predicted probability at the lynch should be exactly the rate at which the lynched player flips scum. You will know how to adjust based on how much and in which direction your prediction deviates.

Now, this was what I was about to post:

Unless you think there is 1 scum in the game, each player's probability of being scum is not 1/(total-1) . Numerator should be the number of scum you anticipate in the game. It should work even if it is a non-integer: e.g. if you think there is equal chance of 5 or 6 scum, then the numerator would be 5.5 .

So every player starts with:

p(Scum)= (#scum in game)/(#players-1)

Then when you find a tell, you decide on:

p(Event|Scum), which is the probability that you would see this tell (Event) occurring if the player were Scum, and
p(Event|Scum'), which is the probability that you would see this Event occurring if the player were not Scum (town)

The plug these into Bayes' Theorem
p(Scum|Event) = [p(Event|Scum)p(Scum)]/[p(Event|Scum)p(Scum)+p(Event|Scum')(1-p(Scum))]

(below calculator found with Google)
http://psych.fullerton.edu/mbirnbaum/ba ... esCalc.htm

You will get the updated probability p(Scum|Event), which is the probability of the player being Scum given that you have observed the Event. If you were 100% correct in your assessment of p(Event|Scum) and p(Event|Scum') as well as the prior probability p(Scum), then the updated probability should also be 100% correct. That is to say, the alignment of the players should be scum exactly at the rate of p(Scum|Event).

Anyways, so you do this to update the probability of the suspect player being scum. Then you do the same with all other players-


And that's where I realized that I haven't thought of this enough.

How do you mathematically account for the updated probability in every player? Take this example: Tell1 increases p(Scum) of player A, and simultaneously decrease p(Scum) of all other players. I was assuming that simply reversing p(Event|Scum) and p(Event|Scum') for all other players would work and the average p(Scum|Event) for all players would still be equal to the original p(Scum). However, what if players A and B both exhibit Tell1? Both of their p(Scum) rises, so obviously you would get a different average p(Scum|Event). Or do you treat them as separate events i.e. Tell1 and Tell2? But that doesn't seem right; the probability of A being scum would be lower when B exhibits the same tell if you calculate it that way, and I can't think of an intuitive explanation for that.

At this point I'm no longer able to see this intuitively, and have not worked out the mathematical proofs necessary, so don't think I can speak much more on this subject at this time. We should start a thread in Mafia Discussion or even on a math forum to enlist some help.

On the points system generally:
It's obviously impossible (and I think it would be a terrible idea) to have a preset list of scumtells, Instead, I basically work things this way:

3-4: "minor"
5-6: "normal"
7-9: "serious"
10+: "major"

In practice, I try to only give out scores of 3, 5, 7 and 10. This is both as a means of minimising emotional influences (so I don't give a player who I have a stronger gut feeling about a slightly higher score) and keeping consistency.
I should also say in advance that a few months ago (and I announced this in the game I started it), I doubled all my scores (as in, I used to mainly give out 1s,2s and 3s). I just say this in case you or anybody else runs off to check my meta on point scoring and then comes back with "Why did this only get 1 point in x game from six months ago?"

As for McG:
McG got 3 points for a tell that I call "boilerplating". The reason this tell only gets 3 is that, in the past (specifically in the game Popularity Mafia, if I recall correctly), I have seen it fail.

(To elaborate on the tell: there are certain scumtells (or alleged scumtells) that have recognised names ("wagoning", "opportunism", "WIFOM", "OMGUS", etc. are common examples). Some of those things are often scummy (eg. "opportunism") whereas others are, in my opinion, not (eg. OMGUS), but that's beside the point. The key point is that, because the tell has a recognised label, using that label effectively serves as an emotional tag to strengthen the argument. It's much easier and sounds much more serious to accuse somebody of "wagoning" than it is to argue that they've cast a vote on an existing wagon for questionable reasons (mostly, I suspect, because "wagoning" imputes a scummy intention to wagon, whereas simply analysing the vote directly might be more ambiguous) The trouble is, as I have learned, town do sometimes also do this, even though in theory the incorrect use of a boilerplate is reflective of a scum mentality.)

The +7 for McG was for two things (I quote the post below): first, his misrepresentation of his past play in respect of IS; and, second, a further instance of him both admitting his scumminess whilst demonising somebody for attacking him. (If you want to really be pedantic, if I had scored the tells separately I would have given the first one 5 and the second 3 (because the second was a repeat of an earlier tell, rather than a new tell in its own right) - but my process of reasoning was more basically "Well, the first of these is a moderate tell, and the second is not so much, so they roughly equate to a serious tell so I will give him 7").

Going through the above:
- The bit about what you "believe" DD was doing is pure conspiracy argument. To quote from one of the few parts of the wiki on scumtells that I endorse:
Wiki wrote: The working definition of a scumtell is an action that is more likely to be taken by a scum player than a town player. This relies on motivations, as most things in mafia do. When a player takes an action, evaluating it on the basis of "would this action more likely come from a town player, or a scum player" should be the way that players determine the scumminess of that action. It is worthwhile to note here that subjectivity plays little to no role in this distinction. POSSIBLE motivations for scum to take a given action are not sufficient to call an action a scum tell. An action is scummy if and only if it can be deemed more likely to come from scum than from town, A perfect example of this occurs in mini 636: Gangland mafia. Kuribo asserts that an action is a scumtell to him, because he can think of A justification for scum to do it, but neglects, as vollkan points out, to show that this reason is likely.

Wiki wrote: The working definition of a scumtell is an action that is more likely to be taken by a scum player than a town player. This relies on motivations, as most things in mafia do. When a player takes an action, evaluating it on the basis of "would this action more likely come from a town player, or a scum player" should be the way that players determine the scumminess of that action. It is worthwhile to note here that subjectivity plays little to no role in this distinction. POSSIBLE motivations for scum to take a given action are not sufficient to call an action a scum tell. An action is scummy if and only if it can be deemed more likely to come from scum than from town, A perfect example of this occurs in mini 636: Gangland mafia. A conspiracy argument is one with the following form:
1) Player X did Y
2) Y is possibly scum-motivated because [reason]
